Justification: To assess for anemia or infection, which could be contributing to jaundice.
To evaluate liver enzymes and bilirubin levels, which can help determine if the jaundice is due to liver dysfunction.
To check for any bleeding disorders, as liver dysfunction can affect blood clotting.
To visualize the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts for any structural abnormalities or obstructions.
To rule out hepatitis A, B, or C as a cause of jaundice.
In case of hemolytic anemia, which can cause jaundice, knowing the blood type is important for potential transfusions.
To assess bone marrow response and rule out hemolytic anemia.
To differentiate between conjugated and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can help narrow down the cause of jaundice.
To check for bilirubin in the urine, which can indicate liver dysfunction or hemolysis.
To check for gastrointestinal bleeding, which can contribute to anemia and jaundice.
